doc.title: Berlusconi escapes eurozone budget rebuke after pledge to lower Italy's deficit
doc.author: Mark Milner
doc.description: Italian prime minister Silvio Berlusconi was yesterday spared the humiliation of a reprimand over his country's budget backsliding on his first day as finance minister - but only after promising a €7.5bn (£5bn) improvement in Italy's public finances.

main.p: Italian prime minister Silvio Berlusconi was yesterday spared the humiliation of a reprimand over his country's budget backsliding on his first day as finance minister - but only after promising a €7.5bn (£5bn) improvement in Italy's public finances.

European Union finance ministers decided not to issue an "early warning" notice regarding Italy's budget deficit after Mr Berlusconi, who took on the finance portfolio at the weekend, detailed a series of spending cutbacks.

In his attempt to shore up the public finances, Mr Berlusconi is planning to cut tax breaks for the financial services sector by more than €1bn as well as pruning subsidies to industry, the regions and state-owned operations, including the rail and postal services.

The Italian prime minister has given himself 10 days to win domestic political backing for his programme, which is designed to keep Italy's public sector deficit within 3% of gross domestic product - the limit set out in the eurozone's stability and growth pact.

Explaining the decision to spare Mr Berlusconi's blushes, French finance minister Nicolas Sarkozy said: "The euro group has taken into account [Italy's] efforts and tries to help countries which makes efforts rather than complicating their task."

France will break the pact's limits for the third year in succession in 2004. Italy's budget sums have been made worse by a near-stagnant economy that has depressed tax revenues but increased spending.
In April the EC recommended finance ministers issue an early warning to Italy as growth projections had been too optimistic and the budget deficit was likely to hit 3.2%.

Public sector debt put at 106% of GDP is also a concern. As the departed finance minister, Giulio Tremonti, who was ousted by some of Mr Berlusconi's coalition partners, noted wryly: "It is difficult to manage the world's third biggest debt pile without being its third biggest economy."

Yesterday's measures may win Mr Berlusconi a breathing space, but he is expected to need further deficit measures next year. Fellow finance ministers appeared confident yesterday that he will be able to achieve them.
"Berlusconi is ambitious to cut the deficit below 3% next year; we trust him," said Austrian finance minister Karl-Heinz Grasser said.
